title: R41839
content: The Dodd-Frank Act established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) within the Federal Reserve System to oversee various consumer financial products and services. The CFPB has regulatory, supervisory, and enforcement authority over institutions offering deposit taking, mortgage lending, credit card lending, loan servicing, and other financial services. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) oversees a wide range of financial products and services, including deposit taking, mortgage lending, credit card lending, loan servicing, and more. It has the authority to enforce federal consumer laws like the Truth in Lending Act and the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act. Some of the CFPB's powers became effective when the Dodd-Frank Act was signed into law in July 2010. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) enforces consumer laws like TILA and RESPA. The Bureau's powers became effective at different times, with most taking effect on the designated transfer date of July 21, 2011. The appointment of a Director also affects the Bureau's authority. The CFP Act grants the Secretary interim authority over the Bureau until a Director is appointed. Section 1066 outlines the Secretary's powers, including the ability for the Treasury Department to provide administrative services before the designated transfer date. The specifics of these services are not defined in the CFP Act. The Treasury Department may provide administrative services to support the Bureau before the designated transfer date. These services are authorized by section 1066(b) and include human resources and access to communication services. The Secretary's interim authorities also come from CFP Act subsection 1066(a). The Treasury Department's administrative support powers under section 1066(b) are in effect from the date of enactment until the designated transfer date. The Secretary's interim authorities, derived from CFP Act subsection 1066(a), allow them to perform the functions of the Bureau until the Director is confirmed by the Senate. These authorities are limited to the functions of the Bureau under subtitle F. Unlike the administrative powers under subsection (b), the Secretary's authorities under subsection 1066(a) do not expire on the designated transfer date. Subtitle F transfers consumer financial protection functions to the Bureau from seven "transferor agencies." The Secretary's interim authority under subsection 1066(a) for functions under subtitle F, transferring consumer financial protection powers from seven agencies to the Bureau, including rulemaking authority. The Bureau will receive authority to prescribe rules and enforce consumer financial laws from various agencies, including the NCUA, FTC, and HUD. This includes rulemaking authority under 18 consumer laws, supervision of larger depository institutions, and coordination with the FTC on rulemaking and studies. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) will have authority over larger depository institutions, including thrifts, savings associations, and credit unions with assets over $10 billion. The Bureau's newly established authorities largely consist of enhanced, up-front supervisory powers over covered non-depository institutions. The CFPB's "newly established" powers include enhanced supervisory powers over non-depository financial institutions, new rulemaking powers, and limited enforcement powers over smaller depository institutions. These authorities were not explicitly provided to federal regulators before the Dodd-Frank Act. The CFPB has enhanced supervisory powers over non-depository financial institutions, including payday loan providers, mortgage brokers, and student loan providers. Subtitle C of the Federal consumer financial laws grants the CFPB authority to issue specific regulations, including declaring acts or practices as unfair, deceptive, or abusive. It also allows the Bureau to require disclosures and establish model forms for consumer financial products and services. Based on available information, the actions taken by the Bureau so far have been administrative in nature or in preparation for future substantive authorities. These actions include engaging with various stakeholders, collecting information on consumer financial products and services, complaints, and coordinating personnel transfers. No regulations have been prescribed, no binding enforcement actions taken, and no supervisory powers exercised over financial institutions. The Bureau has taken administrative steps such as engaging with stakeholders, collecting information, coordinating personnel transfers, and preparing for future authorities. After the designated transfer date, the Bureau will acquire consumer compliance supervisory and enforcement powers over larger depository institutions, as well as rulemaking authority under TILA, RESPA, and other consumer laws. This potential expansion of interim powers could lead to substantive actions impacting financial institutions participating in consumer financial markets. The potential expansion of interim powers by the Bureau could lead to substantive actions impacting financial institutions in consumer financial markets. For instance, the FRB proposed regulations under its TILA authority, including origination standards for certain mortgage lenders. The 474-page proposal was issued on April 19, 2011, open for comments until July 22, 2011. After July 21, 2011, the Bureau will have the authority to prescribe regulations under TILA, including mortgage origination standards. On July 21, 2011, the authority to prescribe regulations under TILA will transfer to the Bureau. Final regulations imposing mortgage origination standards must be prescribed by the Bureau, not the FRB.
